orders and silently continued to walk on in front of the ranks. Suddenly one shot after another rang out from the French, smoke appeared all along their uneven ranks, and musket shots sounded. Several of our men fell, among them the round- faced officer who had marched so gaily and complacently. But at the moment the first re- port was heard, Bagrati6n looked round and shouted, "Hurrah!" 
"Hurrah ah! ah!" rang a long-drawn shout from our ranks, and passing Bagrati6n and rac- ing one anot
